title: I’m filing 13 bankruptcy by myself and they want my bank statements for 2 months. Will they also need my husbands bank account ?
question: I’m just wondering if in chapter 13 bankruptcy they wan my husbands income which I gave them but do I have to show proof of his bank accounts as they want my bank statements.
question_tags: Divorce,Bank accounts in divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Community property in divorce,Divorce and bankruptcy,Divorce and foreclosure,Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy means test,Bankruptcy court,Chapter 13 bankruptcy,Debt,Debt discharge,Bankruptcy and debt,Chapter 13 bankruptcy reorganization plan,Foreclosure
answers: Yes. C13 trustee will need H bank statements.

If you don't know the answer to your question, you should not be filing the case by yourself. Chapter 13 is very complicated for a non-attorney and you will likely end up getting yourself in trouble or having your case dismissed. If you want to have a successful chapter 13 case, then you should hire a chapter 13 attorney in your local area.

The trustee needs to know how much is the total family income in order to make a proper analysis of your Plan. That said, you are making a huge mistake not using a lawyer. Statistics furnished by the US Trustee's Office show virtually all non-lawyer 13s are dismissed. Many BK 13 lawyers will allow you to pay what you can afford up front and then pay off their fees through the monthly Plan payments. BK 13 is not a DIY project.

The short answer is yes. Even if you file alone, his income is counted for the "means test" (statement of "current monthly income.) It is also considered when they look at the actual income on the "I" and"J" schedules. You will need to give the Trustee 6 months of bank statements and 6 months of pay stubs for both of you. This is also an issue because, absent a "prenuptual" premarital agreement his income is community property. In other words, his income belongs to both of you as yours is both of you as well.

Now, to get down to the more important issue, filing on your own without an attorney. The National Association of Chapter 13 Trustees had an article on their website a few years ago. It was captioned as follows: "Chapter 13 + self representation = 0% success rate." Chapter 13 is definitely not a "do it yourself" thing. It is extremely complicated and preplanning on issues can change the situation can change your results dramatically. This could cost you tens of thousands of dollars and be the difference between success and failure. Brain surgery and Chapter 13 bankruptcy have a lot in common. Neither is a "do it yourself" project and always turn out badly for the person that thinks otherwise.

Do yourself a huge favor and see a quality bankruptcy attorney to find out what can be done for you and what is protected. Your case would be filed in the Bankruptcy Court in Sacramento. Your "creditors meeting" will be in Modesto. Your Trustee will be Russell Greer. I would recommend you find a quality bankruptcy attorney by looking at Avvo's ratings for Sacramento or Modesto attorneys.

You could also look at the CA State bar website for a Certified Bankruptcy Law Specialist in Sacramento. Most attorneys will give you are free initial consultation. I have provided a link to the state bar below.

Another potential source for finding a good attorney would be through a search of the National Association of Consumer Bankruptcy Attorneys (NACBA.org) to find a good local attorney. Again, I have provided a link below.

No matter how good an attorney is rated, if you are not comfortable with the attorney when you meet, move on to another attorney. Also, if the attorney uses a paralegal to do the initial appointment, move on because you are just a number and a dollar sign. If this is how you are treated when they are trying to get your money, you can be certain it is not going to get better after they get your money.

Do NOT use an attorney that does anything other than bankruptcy and consumer law and/or foreclosure law. Part-time bankruptcy attorneys are, sadly, never expert enough to do the job right. This is a specialized field and you should go with an attorney who practices solely in that specialty. Choose based on skill rather than price. A bad attorney will cost you way more in the long run. Never hire a non-specialist to do a specialists job. Get the right attorney to begin with.

I hope this helps you.

http://www.nacba.org/find-an-attorney
